This isn't true. It'll attempt to enforce OpenSSL FIPS mode regardless of Python support, but it will fail if the Python version doesn't support it. Hence, this should read like:

  This feature requires Python support. This is available in Python 3.9 in all
  environments and may have been backported to older Python versions on select
  environments. If the Python executable used does not support OpenSSL FIPS mode,
  an exception will be raised.

oslo_cache/core.py.message: This is redundant. If they're seeing this message, they've obviously seeing this message 😄

How about:

  OpenSSL FIPS mode is not supported by your Python version.
  You must either change the Python executable used to a version with
  FIPS mode support or disable FIPS mode by setting the
  '[cache] enforce_fips_mode' configuration option to 'False'.

Also, why _wouldn't_ we hard fail here? The user has explicitly request FIPS mode and we can't provide it. We should crash and burn. If there's a reason we don't want to do this then we should rename the configuration option to e.g. 'attempt_fips_mode' to be obvious about what we're actually doing (note: I wouldn't recommend this)
nit: bit weird that we don't use 'hasattr' here, but what you have does work

oslo_cache/tests/unit/test_cache_basics..message: Rather than doing this, can we mock the attribute and test that we're setting it? As this is designed, we'll actually enable FIPS mode, right (I assume that 'ssl.FIPS_mode_set' is a singleton)
As above, let's not modify global state. Use mock instead.

Ahh, good point. I was wondering why you'd do it this way. What you've proposed works. However, I think we could do it slightly easier. How about simply:

  with mock.patch.object(cache, 'ssl') as ssl_:
      del ssl_.FIPS_mode

      ...

This works because 'autospec' is disabled so the returned object ('ssl_') returns a mock for all object. By calling 'del', we change this.

  >>> import mock
  >>> x = mock.Mock()
  >>> x.foo
  <Mock name='mock.foo' id='139929429536928'>
  >>> del x.foo
  >>> x.foo
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mock/mock.py", line 704, in __getattr__
      raise AttributeError(name)
  AttributeError: foo

Thoughts?
nit: This should probably go at the top of the test since it's not _entirely_ related. Ditto for the other test

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Seems that we might need to revive this, but slightly differently.

Run the upgrade check using a new container (with new code, as we do for DB migrations), before the DB migration.

ansible/roles/nova/tasks/upgrade.yml.message:
should also be executed before upgrade to ensure everything is in place before upgrade, ie: nova cells, min schema version, etc

If something required is missing and we run the db upgrade, could result in database corruption and unable to upgrade, while if we ensure the failure happens before upgrade we haven't touch anything in nova side yet and is safe

That's how I would like this command to work. Unfortunately it is more of a post upgrade check than a pre upgrade check. https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/upgrade-checks.html#guidelines

Haven't check existing checks, but when cells v2 and placement api were introduced all was pre upgrade checks. Ie: check if placement db is created, nova cell is created, etc.

From the docs: Checks are "typically" meant to be run before re-starting and upgrading to new service code.

Where typically doesn't mean always and can exist some cases where the check should be executed before (as new db required or something in the future).

This is the reason why I prefer running check before and after, one for catch pre requirements and second to ensure everything is ok after upgrade

I can bring this up again with the nova team, but my understanding is that the checks are supposed to be run after the DB sync and data migrations. If they depend on some change that happens during those operations then the check will fail.

The upgrade check does not currently check the DB version, but I raised a bug [1] on this and it has been picked up by the nova team. If they fix it then running the checks before DB sync would fail.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1833278

Oops. Good catch.

I need more context to grok this. What exactly breaks in the nova testing if we are not adding this workaround?

I do see oslo_concurrency depends on fasteners directly not nova. Should this WA be applied in oslo_concurrency instead?

Thank you gibi for cracking the case yet again. I was way off 😂

I have opened an issue for eventlet in the hope that someone can shed some light on whether this is expected in eventlet:

https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/731

And if it is, maybe someone can suggest if there is something different that fasteners could or should be doing.

Thanks. So we have pin for fasteners 0.14.1 that we want to remove. 

I'm really afraid of touching the eventlet internals even in our tests as this whole eventlet thing is a complete mess already. I would sleep better if fastener would be patched in our test and not eventlet. 

As of why we have naked greenlets instead of having just GreenThreads I have no idea but I saw that too and it is part of why I think we have a mess.

I also discovered that there are two python threads exists during our test execution. Both threads has its own main greenlet and its own eventlet.hub greenlet. I'm still trying to find why we need two threads.

> As of why we have naked greenlets instead of having just GreenThreads I have no idea but I saw that too and it is part of why I think we have a mess.

I've been reading through eventlet docs and code and I think what we might be seeing is the main greenlet [1], which is the "root" or "parent" and is not a GreenThread. Weirdly the best doc I found about it is a super old version readme for using it with twisted [2].

According to these docs, there should only be one naked greenlet for running main. And it would make sense that is where our tests run from and the only GreenThreads we have are the ones that get spawn()ed from the main greenlet.

So it seems like eventlet's threading.current_thread method is not intended to be called by the main greenlet, only from a GreenThread spawned from it. fasteners is using threading.current_thread to track which thread is holding a lock. I am not sure if this would be considered a bug in either library.

[1] https://eventlet.net/doc/hubs.html#how-the-hubs-work
[2] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/v0.15/README.twisted#L149

Just a side note on the threads probably unrealted to this patch: 

So the additional python thread is from oslo_messaging[1][2] rpc metrics collections. I think we can ignore that.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/feb72de7b81e3919dedc697f9fb5484a92f85ad8/oslo_messaging/rpc/client.py#L185
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/feb72de7b81e3919dedc697f9fb5484a92f85ad8/oslo_messaging/_metrics/client.py#L77-L78

Cool, lets see what the eventlet folks think about this.

I'm also wondering why nova sometimes use spawn, and in other cases use spawn_n. But I did not find any contextual information about this choice from the past.

I have a bit different view on naked greenlets. True there is one naked greenlet which is basically the process that started running when we started the interpreter. As it was not spawned by eventlet it cannot be a GreenThread. BUT there are other naked greenlets. 

One is tight to the eventlet.hub (whatever it is) and becomes the parent of each spawned GreenThread (see [1]). The hub.greenlet created here [2] and it is not wrapped in a GreenThread.

Another source of naked greenlets are the nova use of eventlet.spawn_n() instead of eventlet.spawn(). Based on the code[4] and the doc[3] the spawn_n intentionally does not warp the naked greenlet in a GreenThread for performance reasons (I guess). 

To list running greenlets and GreenThreads I used the trick from the guru mediation code. You can get access to each python object via the GC. e.g:
greenlets = [o for o in gc.get_objects() if isinstance(o, greenlet.greenlet)]
greenthreads = [o for o in gc.get_objects() if isinstance(o, eventlet.greenthread.GreenThread)]

bottom line: 

I think it is not safe to mix spawn_n with ReaderWriterLock as ReaderWriterLock assumes that each entity taking the lock is a GreenThread but in nova we use spawn_n that creates naked greenlets instead of GreenThreads. 

[1] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/8904a339f2df3bd7958e73142d640cd3d0a9245c/eventlet/greenthread.py#L52
[2] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/8904a339f2df3bd7958e73142d640cd3d0a9245c/eventlet/hubs/hub.py#L130
[3] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/8904a339f2df3bd7958e73142d640cd3d0a9245c/eventlet/greenthread.py#L58-L61
[4] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/8904a339f2df3bd7958e73142d640cd3d0a9245c/eventlet/greenthread.py#L158

I got a reply from a eventlet maintainer a couple of weeks ago:

https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/731#issuecomment-953761883

and they indicated (IMO) that spawn_n() is not really compatible with eventlet.current_thread() in that all plain greenlets will return the same native Thread object when eventlet.current_thread() is called.

This leads me to think maybe we should remove spawn_n and use spawn instead so that the environment behaves in a more consistent way and libraries using threading.current_thread work without problems.

The next PS will be trying out that approach. In my local testing of running the tests, there are no failures with fasteners 0.15 when all of our green thread spawns are done with spawn() instead of spawn_n().

Note that the only reason we don't receive the eventlet patched version of current_thread that we need is because our tests are running in greenlets that are not GreenThreads. The eventlet code will only return the patched method if running in a GreenThread and not a plain greenlet. I do not know enough about eventlet to know why they specifically only allow GreenThread for returning the patched version. Could it be a bug in eventlet that it does this? I am not sure.

We hit this error [1] (note the date, 2019) if we use fasteners >= 0.15. The reason is explained in more detail in the issue but the tl;dr is that when fasteners needs to grab the current thread, it will get the unpatched version of current_thread instead of the eventlet patched one.

It's possible that oslo.concurrency would be a better place for the workaround [2]. I don't feel sure about it because on one hand it is a generic problem could theoretically occur for any openstack project that is doing eventlet monkey patching ... on the other hand the nova project seems to be the only one facing the problem, for some reason.

Are we doing something wrong/different in nova than other eventlet monkey patched projects?

I'm interested in opinions on what we should do in order to allow openstack/requirements to bump the upper constraint for fasteners.

[1] https://github.com/harlowja/fasteners/issues/36
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.concurrency/blob/a9ccf0a64deb63e7ea07d232437da797462d8f4b/oslo_concurrency/lockutils.py#L121

So if any of our test depends on a ReaderWriterLock directly from the test code then we still can fail as the test code runs in a naked greenlet as it was not spawned with eventlet. The test results shows that we don't have such test case (or the fault can only happen if two of these naked greenlets are sharing such a lock, but we have only a single naked one). Probably nova in production is safe as both the API requests and the RPC requests are handled in a GreenThread. So only the service startup code has a naked greenlet but those code are not parallel.

> Apologies for not explaining well that it is not oslo.messaging doing the spawn_n ... it is eventlet. oslo.messaging creates a thread.Thread to do some polling [1] and then calls start() on it [2]. The native Thread.start() method [3] calls start_new_thread() [4][5]. And eventlet has patched start_new_thread() [6] and eventlet calls spawn_n() [7].
> 
> So this means that any eventlet patched code using thread.Thread will be calling spawn_n() indirectly which will make all those eventlet thread.Thread appear as the same Thread object according to threading.current_thread(). This seems broken to me.
> 
> There's nothing we can do in oslo.messaging to avoid the spawn_n() other than not eventlet patching the oslo.messaging library in nova, AFAICT. Maybe that is an option? The thing that bothers me about all of this is that, unless I'm missing something, it shows that there are many ways we could break even when we are doing the right thing and eventlet patching everything, because not all things within the eventlet implementations themselves are compatible together ... 
> 

Nothing to apologies for. And thanks for explaining it. I don't think we can simply switch to native threading regarding oslo.messaging that would conflict with other part of the service code that spawning eventlets. I think we have a special handling at such eventlet/native thread boundary in libvirt driver (see nova.virt.libvirt.host.Host._native_thread)

> Probably nova in production is safe as both the API requests and the RPC requests are handled in a GreenThread. So only the service startup code has a naked greenlet but those code are not parallel.

The followup showed that oslo.messaging uses thread.Thread that actually calls eventelt.spawn_n() in a monkey patches service. So our RPC handlers might be not safe with a ReaderWriterLock

I totally agree with you. I also felt from the github discussion that the eventlet maintainer is not really want to change the behavior of spawn_n or the patched threading.current_thread. So we are stuck. 

I'm wondering if we could clearly show the wrong behavior of fastener + eventlet in a small example and post that as an issue to both eventlet and fastener projects. 

Alternatively we can propose a patch to oslo.messaging to switch from spawn_n to spawn and see how they react.

> I totally agree with you. I also felt from the github discussion that the eventlet maintainer is not really want to change the behavior of spawn_n or the patched threading.current_thread. So we are stuck. 

I got the same impression from the github discussion that eventlet does not want to change the behavior of threading.current_thread and agree we are stuck.

> I'm wondering if we could clearly show the wrong behavior of fastener + eventlet in a small example and post that as an issue to both eventlet and fastener projects. 

I think this is a good idea. I will try to work up a better example (using thread.Thread, see the next paragraphs) and post them to both projects.

> Alternatively we can propose a patch to oslo.messaging to switch from spawn_n to spawn and see how they react.

Apologies for not explaining well that it is not oslo.messaging doing the spawn_n ... it is eventlet. oslo.messaging creates a thread.Thread to do some polling [1] and then calls start() on it [2]. The native Thread.start() method [3] calls start_new_thread() [4][5]. And eventlet has patched start_new_thread() [6] and eventlet calls spawn_n() [7].

So this means that any eventlet patched code using thread.Thread will be calling spawn_n() indirectly which will make all those eventlet thread.Thread appear as the same Thread object according to threading.current_thread(). This seems broken to me.

There's nothing we can do in oslo.messaging to avoid the spawn_n() other than not eventlet patching the oslo.messaging library in nova, AFAICT. Maybe that is an option? The thing that bothers me about all of this is that, unless I'm missing something, it shows that there are many ways we could break even when we are doing the right thing and eventlet patching everything, because not all things within the eventlet implementations themselves are compatible together ... 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/feb72de7b81e3919dedc697f9fb5484a92f85ad8/oslo_messaging/_drivers/base.py#L289
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/feb72de7b81e3919dedc697f9fb5484a92f85ad8/oslo_messaging/_drivers/base.py#L296
[3] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/9bf2cbc4c498812e14f20d86acb61c53928a5a57/Lib/threading.py#L931
[4] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/9bf2cbc4c498812e14f20d86acb61c53928a5a57/Lib/threading.py#L34
[5] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/9bf2cbc4c498812e14f20d86acb61c53928a5a57/Lib/threading.py#L950
[6] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/v0.32.0/eventlet/green/thread.py#L47
[7] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/v0.32.0/eventlet/green/thread.py#L72

Yeah ... the troubling part about it is that the spawn_n() is being done by eventlet in patched thread.Thread (oslo.messaging is not intentionally doing it). I'm not sure I understand why they would want an eventlet thread to not be able to be uniquely identified by eventlet threading.current_thread(). As I mentioned on the github issue, that means that all eventlet patched thread.Thread that are created will appear to be the same thread according to eventlet's threading.current_thread() return value.

I am not sure what to do at this point other than to stop using eventlet altogether. I don't feel good about the fact that any library using threading.current_thread() can have undesired behavior with eventlet patched code, where multiple different green threads will appear as one thread object to current_thread().

On the github issue the maintainer showed a hacky way of patching spawn_n() => spawn() globally before calling eventlet.monkey_patch() [1] but he said don't do that in production code. So that does not seem to be an option either.

[1] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/731#issuecomment-968135262

What I am doing here is temporarily swapping threading.current_thread with evenlet.getcurrent (if thread-related modules have been eventlet patched) while creating the lock object only. In this regard, I considered this to be patching only fasteners, but I could also do it another way like:

 self._cell_lock = lockutils.ReaderWriterLock()
 eventlet_patched = eventlet.patcher.is_monkey_patched('thread')
 if eventlet_patched:
     self._cell_lock._current_thread = eventlet.getcurrent

if you prefer.

And if there is yet another way that I have missed that you would prefer, please let me know.
hehe, this was a lie anyhow.

So this restores the workaround that is removed from fasteners >= 0.15 to avoid breaking the lock. Melanie tried to convince both fasteners and eventlet maintainers to fix the issue without any luck. It seems that if we want to keep using the RW lock in an eventlet patched environment like nova then the we have to manually fix eventlet (or fasteners) by ourselves. This is sub-optimal I don't see any viable options that is in our circle of influence. So I'm OK to merge this.

@Melanie: could you add a wrapper for ReaderWriterLock that automatically applies this workaround when the lock is created and add a hacking rule that detects if a patch tries to create a new RW lock with lockutils.ReaderWriterLock() directly instead of using the wrapper? This would prevent future fault when a new RW lock instance is being added to the nova code.

Followup change has been proposed here:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/824280

> @Melanie: could you add a wrapper for ReaderWriterLock that automatically applies this workaround when the lock is created and add a hacking rule that detects if a patch tries to create a new RW lock with lockutils.ReaderWriterLock() directly instead of using the wrapper? This would prevent future fault when a new RW lock instance is being added to the nova code.

Yes, this is a good idea and I will add it as a followup commit per your summary comment.

doc/source/specs/train/approved/2005346-.message:
i would generally read in as "all of" rather than "any of"

can i suggest using 
required=any: and required=all: instead.

and also supporting the mixed case

so /allocation_candiates&...
      &required=all:TRAIT1,TRAIT2
      &required=any:TRAIT3,TRAIT4
      &...

or more succinctly 

so /allocation_candiates&...
      &required=all:TRAIT1,TRAIT2;any:TRAIT3,TRAIT4

'in' is already used elsewhere in other query params (such as member_of on GET /resource_providers ) to mean "at least one of these" and the absense of 'in:' when commas are present already means 'all of these'.

Maintaining grammatic coherence is important. If we were to do it all over again having explicit 'all' and 'any' might have been the right thing to do, but changing it not now isn't really an option.

if that is the established use of in i guess we can favor convention over intuition.

although i woudl also consider depercating in
and intoducing "any" and "all" across the all the api parmater that currenlty support in.
Documented this in the Alternatives section

I see your point, Sean. We currently (e.g. with member_of) have three main cases: any, all, and none (forbidden). The current syntax:

 # all
 member_of=A,B
 member_of=A&member_of=B
 # any
 member_of=in:A,B
 # none
 member_of=!in:A,B
 member_of=!A&member_of=!B  # I think?

This, especially as we get into that last bit, starts to get messy in terms of punctuation, and the following would be more intuitive:

 member_of=all:A,B
 member_of=any:A,B
 member_of=none:A,B

That said, I think such a transition should be made in its own microversion; so unless we're going to land that first, I'm with Chris that we should follow precedent with this one.

cinder/api/contrib/volume_actions.py.message: I wonder whether HTTPConflict would be better here?  The request passes the validation schema, and the problem is that what the user is asking to do conflicts with the state of the resource.
OK, let's split the difference here and go with 400 for consistency, and then we can think about using 409s appropriately in API v4.

I know that there are a lot of different places in the Cinder code where HTTPBadRequest is used.  After reading the definition of 400 (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/400) vs 409 (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/409) I think that Brian's concern is correct.  So, I think using HTTPConflict would be better.  I think there are also other places in the code that we may want to look closer and see if the exception type should be changed.

The request passed schema because we don't know at that time if the volume is encrypted or not, the user know they are performing the operation on encrypted volume and should be aware about the parameters to pass with this request. I see it similar to trying to do an attachment create request on a non-available volume and we raise BadRequest in this case even though the state of resource conflicts with the user request.
I am ok with this approach.  Sounds like a good topic for a future team meeting.

specs/yoga/approved/manila.rst.message: How to we track access nova as requested to a share? e.g. create a cephex key?

one of the requirement for vhost-user is that the memory of the vm is mmap shared, preallocated and has an open file descritor.

there are a few ways to do this but only some are currently supported in openstack.
you can use file backed memory which is enabled via the nova config option or you can use hugepage mameory which is enabeld using hw:mem_page_size=large

the qemu/libvirt exampels use memorry backed memfd with access mode shared.

because of these reqirements we cannot live add the file share to an existing vm unless they were booted with the correct memory backing

i see a few options to adress this.

first we coudl requrie the use of hugepages or file backed memory
second we can extend hw:mem_page_size
    That could either be done by redefineing hw_mem_page_size=small to mean memfd which would be nice as that woudl also 
    allow ovs-dpdk/vhost-user networkign to work without hugepages or we could add a new hw_mem_page_size=memfd
thrid we coudl add a new hw:mem_backing_type=annomous|file|memfd|hugepages extra spec to opt into it.
    hw:mem_backing_type=annomous woudl be effectivly what we have today if you do nothing
    hw:mem_backing_type=file would add a required compute capablity trait  to land on a host with file backed memory
    hw:mem_backing_type=hugepages would just be an alias for hw:mem_page_size=large
    hw:mem_backing_type=memfd would be this new memory backing and can be used for schduleing via a compute capablity trait.

4 we could just always use memfd when not using file or hugepage backed memory.


using memfd has some minor security consideration in that its much simpler if you have host acess to access the memory fo the guest but if you care about that you should use SEV or similar to encypt the guest.



each of the 4 options have pros and cons.

requireign hugepages or file backed memory will be the least amoutn of work but that will also mean that to use this featre your vms must have a numa toplogy  in the case of hugepages even if that is only a numa toplogy of one numa node and will not be able to oversubsibe its memory in both cases.

extending the mem_page_size extra spec/image property with a new memfd value could work but its a little odd since its not related to the memoy size it would still be useing  4k pages and altering the meaning of small to mean memfd means that we could have upgrade/live migration issues so i think that is best avoided.

i thinik adding hw:mem_backing_type is the most explict approch and while it might not be the most intuitive descis to require a new extra spec to be set to use this i think its the cleanest
memfd backed guest do not need to have an explict numa toplogy or numa affintiy from a qemu point of view so 
hw:mem_backing_type=memfd would not need to force numa semantics on the vm. it would avoid any live migration issues
on upgrades but does require the flavors/images to be altered to use this freature which i think is its only real downside.

the final option of just use memfd always if you dont use hugepage or file backed memory i think is also compleing
the main issue that will have is for upgrades. when we upgrade form xena to yoga and live migrate a normal vm with out any extra specs the sorce(xena) host will generate the dest xml without the memfd elements, that will get fixed when the vm is hard rebooted but until then it will not be able to do the attach. we proably can detect that and return an api error (409) indicating that they need to hard reboot the vm and try again but we just need to capture that in this spec and document it for operators if we go this route. the main disadvantage to this si there is no explict schuling in this approch so if you are in a mix xena/yoga env you wont be sure that this will work until you fully upgrade.


not that im not sure "just using" memfd will be a viable option as we will have to confirm if that will disable oversubsrciton or not. it will not require us to numa affine the guest but we need to consider if it has any other impact before we just turn it on which is why im leanting towords hw:mem_backing_type unless we have done some testing with memfd and fully understand its behavior.

For now I think this initial cold attach/detach implementation can just depend on file_backed_memory, I'll write up mem_backing_type as a separate spec and we could potentially switch to it in the future when we introduce live attach/detach?

form the api level we shoudl shares assocated with servers and hide the concept of atachments.
I've decided to meet somewhere in the middle and only expose the attachment UUID to admins.

This should be shareId and I wanted to rename id to AttachmentId to avoid the confusion we had with volume and volume attachment UUIDs.

I really don't mind what we call the endpoint as long as it returns unique UUIDs for the attachment, server and share. All are required IMHO.

*later* sorry I misunderstood what you were suggesting here. As below I still think attachment UUIDs are valid things to list in the response here.

I guess this should be `attaching or attached`?

I might also want to add a status param here.
Metadata service, we could expose that there, but unsure if its needed...
Yeah we can, avoids the need for users to make external API requests to find the tag etc. I'll add this in.
Will this contain ip addresses / passwords? If yes, then would we recreate the problem we have with the cinder host attachments that they are not easy to update if the infra changes?

> Yes it will contain that information but unlike connection_info with volume attachments it will only be used to detach the share. It will not be used to reattach shares during an instance lifecycle, with fresh details been pulled in from Manila.
> 

OK, this sounds good to me.

> We can't do this during the detach because if these backend details were to change somehow we might not be able to detach the currently attached share. I get that for most backends this wouldn't be an issue and we could just `umount` but I worried about corner cases with some of the more exotic backends and this seems like a reasonable approach.
>

ack

as noted above i dont think we should have attachmetns in our api.
we should just model the server to share relation ship and the status.

internally in our db im ok with having an attachment object or binding object but i dont think this should be visable at the api.

to me i think it makes sense for use to also start with a multiplle attachment/binding workflow for move operation so that we can pre bind/attach the share on the destination while its still attach on the source and ensure that work in pre-live migration like we do with multiple port bidnings. i would like the export location to be tracked in a seperate table/object form the assocation of the share and the instance.

Yes it will contain that information but unlike connection_info with volume attachments it will only be used to detach the share. It will not be used to reattach shares during an instance lifecycle, with fresh details been pulled in from Manila.

We can't do this during the detach because if these backend details were to change somehow we might not be able to detach the currently attached share. I get that for most backends this wouldn't be an issue and we could just `umount` but I worried about corner cases with some of the more exotic backends and this seems like a reasonable approach.

As for removing the concept of an attachment from the API I really disagree . It has worked well with volumes and helps users, admins and developers to understand which specific attachments are recorded without having to map the generic server and share UUIDs to something else within the DB etc.

the use of vhost-user rquires that the guest memroy is mmaped shared and its accable via an open file discriptor in stead of mapped as annomous. This will allow read/write access to the guest memory form the host if you have the currect user/group access. not this is alreay true for filebacked memroy and hugepages so this is a minor securtiy regression and its a feature that is sometime used by securtiy scanning tools to detech malious guests in the case of file backed memory already so it has some advantacge too since it makes the eaiser without the performce hit that can happen with file backed memory.
Virt-io resize, does the kernel see those changes? Does it really matter?
Resize isn't covered by this spec.
Note to self: we normally wait for libvirt release before merging the spec.
Yup and note this is about future work for live attach etc, something not covered as part of this spec.

hooks/nova_cc_utils.py.message: The OpenStack team tends to prefer .format() rather than % for string formatting these days, which I know is contra to how most of this charm is done, but we try to garden a little where we can!
This whole function should probably be part of the context in c-h.

Please could we use """ for docstring comments (as opposed to ''') and start the title of the docstring on the same line.  This is per the OpenStack charmers coding guidelines: https://docs.openstack.org/charm-guide/latest/coding-guidelines.html

Although this is good to check, it's not actually necessary.  Charm-helpers is synced into the charm, so either it's there with this change, or it's not.

So the idea is to the charm-helpers (c-h) change merged, then sync it to this charm as part of your change (make sync) and then submit it as part of the review.  It's important to land the c-h change first, though.

Then you don't need the try/except as it will be available in the c-h that's part of this charm.

FYI only (as this code is going to be removed) If you use split strings, then you don't need the continuation marker and it looks a little neater:

    hookenv.log('....'
                '....',
                level=...)
As this charm runs under py3, should this be 'rt' rather an 'r' (i.e. config_template should be a str rather than bytes?)
This probably doesn't want to be done for every config-changed hook.  As long as the __call__ method in the context picks up the config parameters, then it would only need to be registered once.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
if this is the operation you care about specifically then you shoudl
instead add a direct refesh of the instance info cache wehn the floatign ip is added
Yes, operations floatin assocaitae/disassociate. That would be on neutron code side then, right ?

issue appears using both `openstack server add flaoting ip` and `openstack floating ip set`

I am a bit confused. It doesn't seem I go throught the code you mentioned even after adding some debug in the code. Also there's this comment : 
> """This API is deprecated from the Microversion '2.44'."""

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/floating_ips.py#L179


``openstack --debug server add floating ip`` shows that the API called is the neutron one, with such queries :

> "GET /network/v2.0/floatingips/111.222.333.444 HTTP/1.1"
> "GET /network/v2.0/floatingips HTTP/1.1"

The decorator refresh_cache is indeed loaded when nova-api starts but looks to me that it is never used...

server side : debian nova-api 2:22.2.2-1~bpo11+1 
client side : python3-openstackclient 5.2.0-0ubuntu1

both in nova the api is implemented here
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/floating_ips.py#L186-L300

which calls neutron via 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutron.py#L2545-L2616

we actully have a conditional refersh of the network info cache already.

to resolve your issue w likely need to alway refesh the network info cache instead.

so at first glance after the current update of the old port you would  need to add an update of the new port
e.g. ``update_instance_cache_with_nw_info(context,instnace)`` at
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutron.py#L2580
however that function is decorated with refresh_cache
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutron.py#L132-L158
which does this automatically.

so if you associate the floating ip with the instance via the nova api we are already doing the cache refersh correctly.

if you are associateing the ip via neutron then neutron need to send a network-vif-changed external event to refresh the cache.
the recomended way to manage floatign ip assignment was previously to only do it via nova so perhaps neutron has a bug and does
not send the network vif plugged event if you bypass nova and do the association directly in neutron.

``openstack server add floating ip`` shoudl be useing the nova api.

is this how you are adding the floating ip or are doing it via neutron with 

``openstack floating ip set --port <neutron port> [--fixed-ip <port private ip>] <floating ip>``

this will associated the fip with the vif via neutron without invoking nova fip add or remote apis.

as a result this will only be refected in the network info cache if netorn send the netwrok-vif-chagned external event or the perodic task runs. neutron should do the former. if it does nto its a bug that hsould be fixed there.

Changes seem fine to me.  I think once Eric tries it, and the -p is fixed, its probably ready
I'll take this version for a test drive.

The recent patch update does work.
However, unfortunately this update does not actually fix the reported issue
which is to be able to collect from a subcloud if its configuration fails which could leave its hostname as its subcloud name.

Testing this failure scenario reveals that the subcloud collect is rejected because the subcloud controller is not active (because it failed configuration).

    Error: not active ; failed to collect from subcloud1 [remote] (reason:35)

The reason for this is that the collect command sent to the subcloud uses the -a (or --all) option which commands that host to collect all hosts. Unfortunately the --all option requires that controller to be active so that it can query system inventory for the list of provisioned hostnames.

In this case that fails cause the subcloud controller is not active.

This would also hold true if the customer on a normal system executes 'collect -a' on a system that is not active. Normally they would have to change the command to just do a local 'collect' with no -a option. This is not possible for the subcloud collect since the -a option is auto specified.

This update needs a further enhancement to print a warning rather than error out if an attempt is made to use the --all option on a host that is not active and then proceed to collect from self without the dependency of being active (and sysinv running).

I have implemented a prototype of this change and will share that with the author once tested as a formal patch change.

oslo_limit/limit.py.message:
This seems dangerous to me. Presumably there's not much someone can do to mess this up by choosing their project_id, but registered limit names could be a potential clash. Imagine if I'm confused about what a registered limit is supposed to be, and I create one with the name being the uuid of one of my tenants. I might cause this code to fetch a limit when it's expecting to fetch a project {name:limit} dict.

Maybe we could namespace the keys here to prevent that? Or maybe even better, just have a registered_limit cache and a project cache?
Hm, yeah, I didn't consider the possibility of collisions due to project_id as registered limit name. I think it'd be simpler to just use separate caches (as opposed to namespacing).

I think this would be a lot simpler if you always make the cache a dict, and only *store* the value if caching is enabled. Then you don't need so many conditionals. So:

 if project_id in cache:
     return cache[project_id]

 limit = get_actual_limit()

 if should_cache and limit:
     cache[project_id] = limit

 return limit

Unrelated to this patch, I find this really confusing personally. When there's no limit found for DISK_GB, for example, the message is:

designate/central/service.py.message: The issue here is that this code was most likely written before the concept of recordsets were introduced. The problem it causes is that a recordset can have a mix of managed and un-managed records, and if only un-managed records exists, the command would fail because it would try to create a new recordset, but one already exists, and fail.

This changes the code to only look for the master NS record for the zone e.g. zone.example.org will now only match the NS record zone.example.org. and never additional records created under a different name e.g. NS hello.zone.example.org.

Maybe also improve the wording of this message? Since instead of "No", actually too many recordsets were found.

otoh I'm not sure whether this can actually happen with the new search criteria. Those would be duplicate recordsets that shouldn't have been allowed to be created in the first place? That would even allow us to use find_recordset() above instead of find_recordsets().
Yep - you are right. Will fix.

I'm not sure whether dropping the "deepcopy" here is valid. Deleting from recordset.records while at the same time iterating over it sounds dangerous at least. Not sure what the actual python semantics for this would be.
Ah yea - good catch. I changed it to a list that should be a more modern approach to this.

The code flow here is almost entirely unchanged. The only real difference is that if obj_attr_is_set is false for ns_records we just exit out and return the update_pool object. Previously this could generate a nasty exception since create_ns / delete_ns wouldn't exist.

Thanks for working through the release note

The fix seems fine to me.

I am assuming we cant (without major headaches) move these calls down into puppet.

This can potentially hold up CLI commands and other processes for 30s, and then still fail. Is that the behavior we want?

The join command is only used on first unlock. Would it be safer to just not generate the join command if the apiserver is down? I've only seen these types of issues with runtime manifests.

Based on the logs we had multiple runtime manifest calls that induced this error. An initial manifest call that restarted the API server then another call that failed because the API server was restarting.
My concern is twofold. 1) During upgrades I've seen the API server take longer than 30s to restart, so this fix may only cover some cases. 2) This can add (during api restarts) a 30s delay to the puppet generation. That may induce errors in the parent API calls, eg the sysinv API calling the conductor, or the system controller calling a subcloud's API.

So the question is do we understand and accept those risks.

Are you concerned about a case with a runtime manifest where the apiserver is down? The only difference in that case would be holding up for 30 seconds. The issue we are trying to solve here is in the first time unlock. I believe there will be no join command at all unless we generate one. In this case, the apiserver is not down permanently, but down due to being restarted to pick up a new CA certificate.

I haven't seen any docs around system-id requirements to be UUID, but it seems Neutron has gone with that assumption, given that ovs-ctl/ovn-ctl are setting that.

Still, there's no bug - and more politeness please.
Second of all - since it's impacting users - you need to provide a proper reno and ideally an additional task that will mitigate the impact of this change.
Cool but what about the ovs/ovn side? In their documents, it seems it should/better to be UUID!

Based on these two facts system-id should be UUID:
1. In ovs-ctl it says that system-id should be UUID: https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/utilities/ovs-ctl.in#L407-L409
2. In neutron code here it is trying to parse system-id as a UUID and if it's not UUID it will be failed and so neutron-ovn-metadata-agent won't be registered because it raises an exception and based on its wrapper it will always retry without any errors: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/ovn/metadata/agent.py#L266
